intro: Dipcadi setosum var. readii, commonly known as the hairy tunicate, is a flowering plant native to parts of southern Africa. It belongs to the Amaryllidaceae family and is characterized by its tubular, often hairy leaves and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to arid or semi-arid conditions. Its flowers are usually white or pale pink and bloom in late summer or early autumn. The species is valued for its ornamental appeal and is sometimes cultivated in gardens for its unique appearance.
